ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We covered several different types of games at a simple level where we'd calculate payoffs and consider strategies as well as consider them in general contexts with proofs and theorems.
I improved my math skills, as well as my economic critical thinking skills.

Different methods on cooperation in game theory or competition within game theory along with mathematical and proof applications. Majority of the time was focused on apply Shapley's concepts to our work.
Cooperative game theory, we talk alot about the Shapley value
Game Theory
Lots of applications to real-life phenomena. Game theory is everywhere!
This course allowed me to delve deeply into game theory concepts. I previously took the course Game Theory and Political Science, and this course built and expanded on the skills I learned.

In this class, I was able to learn how to think about game theory concepts in a slightly new and unique framework. This class is really cool because game theory is usually taught in a competitive framework, but this class flips that on its head and teaches quantitative theories on how and why people cooperate.
I learned about cooperative game theory concepts.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think some of the proofs were difficult to follow or to at least think of ourselves without being guided in the right direction. Working out examples was the key way for me to understand a concept rather than looking at the proofs first.
Expansion of material that is learned in introductory econ courses. Great professor who is very knowledgeable and makes the course material manageable. No weaknesses.

The course's strengths are that the teaching and information is very clear and easy to review back, especially for any assignments or graded material. The professor is willing to answer any questions, so he is very helpful. One thing that could improve the class would be to add a TA for student assignments, but the teacher was a great resource.
The professor is great and obviously cares a lot, it's just hard to run a Friday morning seminar via Zoom. The class is pretty straightforward though.
It was very unorganized but the professor was very nice. There should be more office hours and other helpful review sessions.

The professor is a very talented and smart game theorist. He genuinely cares about the well-being of his students and their continued academic success and learning. I truly enjoyed working with him. One weakness of the course is that sometimes the material was hard to follow. Perhaps a consequence of the virtual environment, but I found myself lost on many of the topics. Additionally, there were no TA's or peer tutors to turn for and we were not allowed to work on the problem sets with others, making it extremely difficult to receive outside help.
could be better organized but Pradeep was chill

I think that the material of this course was extremely interesting, but it was sometimes tough to attend lectures on Friday mornings. In addition, Professor Dubey is such an amazing, kind person, but the class materials were extremely disorganized, making it hard to find materials and notes.

Strengths: Professor Dubey is great and the material is very interesting
Weaknesses: The course is a little disorganized at times.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Because attendance wasn't mandatory, many students didn't attend the live virtual lecture on Zoom but instead watched the recording of it at a later time/date. Therefore not too many students were in class at the same time and one time only two/three students attended lecture.
The class being recorded was a great help as we could rewatch material we found confusing.

The recording was essential as I was always very tired by Friday. When going to class directly, I would always fall asleep, so I needed the recordings to have full engagement with the class. There are no improvements needed for how the online teaching was handled during this semester.
Recorded lectures

I think that it was awesome having recorded lectures, as the recorded lectures were extremely useful to refer to when working on problem sets and the final essay. However, it was often daunting to schedule office hours with Professor Dubey, and it was hard to engage and participate in lecture on Friday mornings. It was also extremely tough paying attention to the course sometimes due to a unorganized course schedule.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 3 Psets a midterm and final. Both midterm and final were basically psets. Professor is nice and works with students to make sure the course is well paced. Very good spring semester senior course

I think this course is a pretty low workload senior seminar in the Economics major but students outside of the major with some mathematical background would be able to keep up with the material as well. Some of the games and theorems you learn are interesting and make sense when playing with the example problems but became difficult and mundane when considering their proofs and general cases. If you really want to understand it, you may need to read through any of the notes in Canvas or material online.
Yes if a student is an econ major who is interested in game theory.
Yes. If you are willing to put in the effort to learn the concepts related to the work and prepare for the final paper and midterm appropriately, then this class will be an enjoyable experience.
Yeah sure, would probably be better off of zoom. This was the first ECON class I had every taken (I'm an applied math major) and the prereq isn't necessary.
No, it was too disorganized.
Absolutely, it's very fun and lots to learn
pradeep dubey is such a g and was so incredibly accommodating during covid.. if you like game theory take it! he is so passionate about the subject field

I would recommend this course to anyone with an already FIRM understanding of game theory. I came into the course already having completed a game theory class, and still found the material to be extremely challenging. However, the professor is great and the workload is relatively low (yet VERY hard), so depends on what the student is looking for.
maybe yes if it's in person

I would recommend the course for those looking for a easy yet interesting senior seminar. This class is extremely relaxing compared to other courses in the economics major, though that may be the result of the online learning format of this year.
Yes! Professor Dubey is amazing. The course is lighter on workload but still super interesting and engaging if you like game theory.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lectures were recorded on Zoom to be viewed later.
Recorded lecture.
lectures recorded
Live virtual lecture
N/A
The seminars were also recorded and posted on Canvas.
Live virtual lecture but also recorded
